according to Dr. Muller,
especially because the school did
not receive any natural gas last
winter and was forced to increase
the amount of oil purchased. Dr.
Muller also pointed out that
unlike most undergraduate
colleges, Hopkins could not shut
down many buildings, because of
the many research facilities used
during winter recess. According
to a report distributed by Dr.
Muller at the meeting, the
University has actually decreased
energy consumption, although
the total fuel bill has increased
some one-and -a-half million
dollars since 1973.
When asked about why tile
Consumer Price Index for the

University was higher than that
of the nationwide CPI, Dr. Muller
replied that unlike the rest of the
nation, the University deals
mostly with books, utilities,
paper, etc., which have increased
faster in price than such
commodities as food, clothing,
and transportation, which the
University does not deal with.
Following a 27 minute talk,
President Muller spent the next
hour answering questions. Dr.
Muller explained that the
University is not asking the
students to pay all the costs, and
that in fact Hopkins is less
dependent upon tuition fees than
most schools. He noted, however,
titat the increase is necessary to
protect the University
endowment.
President Muller expressed his
dissatisfaction with the federal
and state scholarship systems, for
the uncertainty of such national
programs make budgeting all the
more difficult a task. "The
complications now in the
Department of Health, Education
and Welfare, and the U.S. Office
of Education are enormous," he
commented, "and the Maryland
state scholarship system is
lousy." .

usually don't make that decision
until much later in the year,"

SC to Establish Book Co-o
BY KATHLEEN TROY
The Student Council has
proposed the establishment of a
book co-op on campus which
would offer texts to students at a
lower price than those currently
Offered by the Hopkins Book
Center, the University-based
bookstore. The proposal is not a
new one; the Student Council has
discussed the possibility of setting
Up a co-op for several years. But
if the plan materializes this time,
Hopkins students will be able to
order books at a discount price
starting next semester.
In past years, proposals for the
establishment of a book co-op
have raised questions about the
legality of such a move. The

University has a contract with
Follett's which prohibits the
introduction of a competing
establishment on campus. Dave
Chcsanow, President of the
Student Council, said that the
proposed co-op will not interfere
with the University's contract
because Follett's handles a wide
range of books and supplies that
the co-op will not.
Initially, the co-op will offer
only books for courses that are
being given regularly—either for
the first or second semesters—and
only those books that are
commonly used, required texts.
Books will not be ordered for
courses that are being offered for
the first time or that have a very

limited number of students. In
the beginning, the co-op will try
to benefit the greatest number of
students. Therefore books for
lower-level, and required courses
will probably be the only ones
available. After the co-op nas
established a reliable credit
record with the publisher, books
may be offered for a wider range
of courses.
The co-op would operate out
of the small room across from
the Student Council office on the
second floor of Levering Hall. At
first, students would place orders
for books at the end of the
previous semester, paying cash
when ordering and receiving the

BY TYRONE SLOTHRUP
Students of the Peabody
Conservatory will take the first
step aimed at restoring student
government there this Monday
and Tuesday, when they vote on
•
a proposed constitution.
The constitution, which wi.s
drawn up this summer by an ad
hoc committee, was basically
modelled on the Hopkins
Student Council constitution.
Once the preliminary bersion had
been drawn up, it was presented
to the student body at large on
the 21st and 28th of this month.
Revisions were discussed and
voted 'upon, and incorporated in
the final version to be presented
in the referendum.
As with most student
governments, the officers shall
consist of a President,
Vice-President, Secretary and a
Treasurer. Unlike Hopkins,
however, the representatives will

not be selected by class? rather,
they will be elected by musical
categoiy.
According to the proposal,
there will be nine categories
which will have representatives.
These are: 1.Keyboard; 2.Strings
and Harp -,. 3.Woodwinds; 4.Brass
and Percussion, 5.Voice;
6.Graduate and Undergraduate

go for the idea of codes 'falling
into disuse.' Laws don't die out,
they're neglected or obscured,"
Mr. Chesanow commented.
According to Mr. Chesanow,
the failure of Dr. Muller to have
the Board ratify the code was
just another step in a long line of
apparent abuses of authority by
the University President.
Dr. Muller gave a differing
explanation for his lack of action
on the code. "The code was
adopted when the position of
Dean of Students was new, so a
fair amount of time and effort
went into making it, and I did
advise the Trustees about it—yet
I quite deliberately did not take
it to the Board for approval so
that it would formally go into
effect. Frankly, we wanted to
gain some experience in such
matters before we locked
ourselves in. By the end of the
year it became apparent that the
kinds of cases that former Dean
of Students Fitzpatrick was
dealing with—and virtually all of
those which Dean Hall has
handled—didn't really lend

themselves to being solved by the
code."
Dean Hall, who succeeded
Dean Fitzpatrick, has said that he
never saw a copy of the code:
"When students came before me
I didn't even mention the code.
It had fallen into disuse. When I
had to make a disciplinary
decision, I simply gave them the
word. Yet I always let the
students know that they had a
right to appeal, The
Administration, though, has
always had the last voice in such
matters."
Presently, the Student
Council's Issues Committee
under Gerry Spada is working on
a new code, and each week
various aspects of it are
discussed. Says Mr. Chesanow,
"We should have it completed by
the end of tile year, hopefully by
the end of the semester. We're
working on it as fast as we can,
bat this time it's going to have to
carry some weight."
Although he has been
operating for four years without
one, Dean Hall is enthusiastic
about the possibilities of a new
code. "Student Council is saying
we should have a part in our own
governance—we are mature
enough to have a part in the
disciplinary process," he
commented. "That's good. It's
part of a very positive Hopkins
tradition of the students taking

responsibility for themselves."
However, President Muller,
who has the last word on the new
code, is not so sure that
unmitigated student and faculty
participation in the disciplinary
process is worthwhile. "The code
was developed retrospectively
when there was some
apprehension on Dean
Fitzpatrick's part that we would
have incidents that might hark
back to the 1960's. We haven't
had incidents like that. In terms
of our experience, I'm not sure
we need a code. That is, we have
in effect operated, for some time
without one. However, that
doesn't mean that I'm opposed
to havipg one and I can foresee
future circumstances where it
would be useful."
Dr. Muller thinks that tile new
code "should be sufficiently
flexible that it could be useful."
Mr. Chesanow agrees in principle.
"The most bidding code will be
the simplest one," he said. "Any
code that is too strict will allow
too mu ,.:h room for
circumvention::
A major aspect of the new
code, according to Mr.
Chesanow, would be a provision
for the formation of a panel
composed of students, faculty,
and administration to dear
special disciplinary cases.
"Perhaps a disciplinary panel
modeled after that of the Ethics

Board is not a bad idea—that
might be the perfect safeguard
against this code falling into
disuse."
Dr. Muller is amenable to the
possibility of a judicial
disciplinary panel, but he would
not want it to override the main
purpose of the Dean of Students'
Office—to handle problems of a
personal nature that involve at
most only three or four students.
"I think what the code has to

preserve is a great deal of
discretion for the Dean of
Students to deal with a case in a
more counseling than judicial
role," he ,commented."Yet if we
had student conduct of a public
and extracurricular nature that
seriously inconvenienced other
students, conduct that would be
susceptible to some sort of
judicial proceeding, then I think
•it would be a good idea to have a
code."

Dollars for Scholars
Big Bucks for the Asking
BY BRUCE SMITH
"More Hopkins students
Should apply for post-graduate
scholarships," according to
Student Council President Dave
Chesanow.
Many scholarships are available
for post-graduate studies, yet few
Hopkins students have applied
for them this year. "It's not a
question of capabilities; there are
many Hopkins students who are
Perfectly qualified," said Mr.
Chesanow. "It's bad news that
more students haven't applied.
The personal benefits and
satisfaction of winning such a
scholarship, not to mention the
added prestige that Hopkins
would enjoy, are enormous."
Information and application
materials are available in Dean
Sigmund Suskind's office at
Homewood House.
The Marshall Scholarship
Provides the opportunity to

study in England for two years,
and is open to any U.S. citizen
under 26 years of age with a
good academic background. The
Scholarship is an expression of
British gratitude for the Marshall
Plan. An effort is made to place
the candidate in the British
University of his or her choice.
The endorsement of the Dean is
required so that a transcript,
three letters of recommendation,
a curriculum vitae and the
program of study -proposal must
be received in the Dean's office
by October 10.
Rhodes Scholarships provide
an opportunity to study at
Oxford for two or three years.
The Rhodes, awarded for
intellectual ability and physical
vigor, is open to any singleU.S.
citizen, 18 to 24 years old, with a
bachelor's degree earned by

But the music! It grabs me and suddenly I am dancing.
Stomping or swinging a partner, running in time with the
beat, hopping like a kid on a hot brick. Sweat streams
down from behind my ear, but so long as they play I can
keep jumping! When the song ends, I find I am wrung out.
Looking around, people crumple to the ground. But if I'm
not out of the crowd before the next set, I can't help but
spring alive. Feet moving like fingers on a banjo string.
Connection between audience and musicians is mutually
electric. Dance, pick, scream, saw that fiddle in two!
It's easy to get close to people, not only to dance.
Between the stage and stands there is no light except
cigarette ends and haphazard flashlights. No one will get

by a match are always soft, friendly. I realize my

doesn't have to be.
Curled under a sleeping bag on the hood of his car, a
sliver of dew runs down my forehead. The campgrounds
have not been stillAll night. Harmonica player passes in
the dim and first morning birds harmonize. I tell my
friend see ya later. Have to catch the dawn.
Maybe from being in the mist as the sun crawled above,
maybe exhaustion, lends some slowness to tne second
morning. The crowd as a whose is up, dancing, drinking,
charging jeeps and cycles at each other. But I hang at the
edges until afternoon, talking about unseen places or
minding the store. As gn.dually recharging, my sunburned
arms start to itch. I wrestle my way to the front before
David Bromberg comes on; been waiting for this one.
Someone's cooler makes me a foot taller than those
around me, except when I step down to take out beer. I
tie my shirt up and boogaloo. A roadie wz,ves back when I
wave, Bromberg smiles back when I yell out a request.
(And I know I'm not mistaken, he sang it right to me.)We
scream out the chorus: "You know that same rowdy
crowd that was here last night is back again." After two
encores, I see Bromberg signal to the announcer, no more,
and I wriggle 19.ck out of the crush.
Packing up that evening, I calculate my last seven days
have only included four of sleep. We underhand bread,
cigarettes, hotdogs, everything into the reefertruck.
Impatient, groggy, but still able to tapdance when the
music is right. Turn the customers away. I watch my pack
squashed into the trunk, repeat my address and curl in the
back seat. Can't help but crash...

Injuries left holes up and down
the Blue Jay defensive line, and it
seemed that the Muhlenberg
Mules found every one of them
as they galloped by the
Homewood boys 38-12.
The competition doesn't seem
as if it is going to let up, either,
as the Jays travel tomorrow to
Lancaster, Pennsylvania to meet
perennial Middle Atlantic
Conference, Southern Division
powerhouse Franklin and
Marshall.
The Mules of Allentown,
Pennsylvania ran rampant over
the Jay defense as they rolled up
an awesome rushing total of 414
yards through the efforts of
junior running back Gerald Fahy
(20 carries for 200 yards),
sophomore running back Brian
Bodine (18 carries for 112
yards), and junior quarterback
star John Schlechter (15 carries
for 81 yards). This total is more
awesome if one considers the fact
that John Sules, last year's top
running back, not only for the
Mules but for the entire division,
was sitting on the bench with an
injured knee. Coupled with
Schlechter's performance in the
air (7-13 for 93 yards), the Mules
net offensive yardage count of
507 eclipsed the Jays' meager
offense that mustered a paltry 99

yards (83 on the ground and 16
through the air on four
completions out of 12 attempts
by Jay signal caller, Bob
DeSimone).

"We made quite
a few mistakes,"
says a behooved
Coach Denny Cox
Two early running bursts by
Schlechter and Fahy beat the
Jays into submission and put the
game out of reach before the ten
minute mark rolled by in the first
quarter. After the Mules',
recovered the ball on their own
39 yard line by way of an
interception of a DeSimone pass,
Schlechter marched his team 61
yards for six points. The Mule
QB capped off the scoring drive
himself by bootlegging the final
23 yards around the Blue Jay
right side.
The Jays enjoyed a shortlived
tie before the Mule offense
again exploded.. A 1 -yard plunge
by frosh runner Bernie Cook

topped off a 64 yard drive spear
headed by key clipping penalties
charged to the Muhlenberg
defense and a nifty 24 yard
gallop by senior Ken Bess. Just a
f3w plays later, though, the game
was put away. Fahy on a second
and ten situation on his own 26
yard line took the handoff from
Schlechter and busted through
the Jay front line and then
outraced the Hopkins secondary

for a 74 yard scoring play.

Life in the Trenches: Thankless Task

•

There are certain
sports at Hopkins that do not
attract great amounts of
attention no matterhow good or
pathetic their season records have
been .. Football is one of those
sports whose record has not been
anywhere near wonderful.
Because of this, 200 fans at the
opening game of the year was all
that turned out. The players,
coaches, and others involved in
the program, though, work as
hard as any other sport. As a
matter of fact, the majority of
the coaches and assistants are
volunteers.
So what do they get for their
effortsi Last year their record
was 3-5-1, 200 fans a game, and
virtually not enough players to
have practices where the coaches
can afford to do any ersatz
hitting. Why do the electrical
engineers and pre-med students
then bother to take the time to
come out for a losing team?
Rick Law, center and
sophomore from Baltimore, is a
superb example of what athletics
at Hopkins are all about. An
environmental engineer major, he
gets none of the breaks that a
football player at University of
Maryland would get. None of the
cars, special tutors, special food,
special dorms, as a matter of fact
the football squad here gets no

special anything. The students
don't even appreciate his
dedication by showing up for the
games.
What Rick does get is a
tremendous sense of a job well
done, camaraderie, and a chance
to get out on that field and
release the tremendous amount
of pressure that the academics
place on aperson at JHU. And he
is good at the center position.
Head coach Denny Cox describes
Law as more than just a super
person. "He's dedicated, loyal
and hardworking, I can't say one
bad thing about him. He does not
rely on pure strength or ability to
get the job done. He leans heavily
on technique. He's the most
consistent offensive linesman for
the past two years."
Student coach Bill McEnroe
only duplicates the coach's high
praise of the team's center.
"Ricky's doing the work in the
trenches. He blocks for the
backs. Most people watch the
ball, and never see the linesman
who tre doing the bulwark. But
they don't want credit. Their
satisfaction comes form within.
When our team scores, within the
team its know who has made the
blocks."
Law himself doesn't want the
credit. "No recognition doesn't
bother me. If I have a good

block, a touchdown block, it's
better than if I was running with
the ball. I work all week for
Saturday. If it was good then I
feel good. If it was a bad game,
then it was all a waste. It ruins
the rest of my weekend. But you
have to put it out of your mind.
But I'll get my credit sooner or
later, the whole team will.
The stereotype that surrounds
football players just doesn't exist
at Hopkins. Jocks aren't
admitted on the basis of their
athletic prowess only. They go
through he regular admissions
process just like the rest of the
students here. Law would never
give up his future in
Environmental engineering to
play at a school like The
University of Maryland with a
superiOr football program, but
terribly inferior academics. "I
wouldn't give up engineering to
play for Maryland. They can't
guarantee the future. 1.m happy
to go to school here. Of course at
Maryland the partying isn't
limited to Saturday like it is here.
Of course at Maryland the
partying isn't limited to Saturday
like it is here. But we only party
here as much as anyone else. I'll
only go to disco night if I have
my work done."
"It's tough coming here as a
freshman and trying to play

football, and study. It's tough
having to do the work without
the athletics, and then add in
three hours a day practicing, plus
the two weeks that come to
school early and live in the dorms
before orientation. Then on top
of everything, the high school
stars that come here expect some
amount of crowds, and then they
get nothing."
The entire football situation at
the Hop then must revolve
,,round something other than the
fans and fringe benefits. The
reward must be personal. Rick
Law is an unsung hero in the
offensive line and an unadmired
football player at Hopkins knows
that only too well." You have to
enjoy it. Some at Hopkins knows
that only too well. "You have to
enjoy it. Some guys are so
emotionally involved after a loss.
You just have to put it out of
your head. No fans affect my
playing only in that I'm not quite
as keyed up as I could be if there
werer a few thousand out there
instead of two hundred.
Physically though it doesn't
affect me that much. I'm ready
emotionally and physically. Of
course it would be an incentive
to play harder if fans were out
there."
BY CHRfISTY JO ANDERSON

BIA
BY JOHN L. BRANDEIS
The Bureau- of Intramural
Athletics (BIA) operating under a
new set of by-laws has opened
the season with flag football.
Participation is high. with six
frats, seven independents, and
nine dorms fielding teams. A
minimum of seven players are
required per team, but generally
there are ten or more eligible
members on each squad. The
frats and independents form one
league with the dorms comprising
another. At the end of October,
the respective league champions
will meet in a final game.
Since this is a contact sport
women are not allowed to play,
but are welcomed in all
non-contact sports. In the past,
co-ed volleyball has been quite
popular,and this year in the
interest of forming a varsity team
there will also be volleyball just
for women.
Other BIA events soon to take
place include the annual Goucher
Gallop, which will he on October
9. It is two and a half miles long,
and if interested contact Steve
Taitz, Box 954. A tennis
tournament in both singles and
doubles competition is currently
scheduled for the same weekend
but may be changed to the
following week. This weekend a
seven mile bike race will occur at
Lake Montebello. It is slated to
I start at 12:30 on Saturday.

Lacrosse
The Johns.Hopkins University
varsity lacrosse team will meet
the Hopkins Alumni under the
lights of Homewood Field on
Saturday, October 1, tomorrow,
at 8 P.M. The public is invited to
attend the out-of-season contest
for which there will be no
admission charge.
The Alumni team will feature
many nationally prominent
lacrosse stars, including two
All-Time super-stars, Jack
Thomas and Joe Cowan, each of
whom was considered the best of
his era. Among other
All-Americans to appear for the
Alumni are Stan Fine, presently
Director of the Maryland State
Lottery, and Mt. Washington
midfielder, Stan Kowalchuk.
Also playing will be Mt.
Washington defense star, Dennis
Townsend, who last spring was
selected to play for the USA
World Team.
The star-studded alumni team
includes several former standouts
who are now in the active
coaching ranks. Charlie Coker is
assistant coach at UMBC, Lucky
Mallonee coaches at Park School,
Jim Moorehead is the coach of
newly powerful Wroxeter, and
Downey Slafkosky is assistant
coach at West Point.
The Blue Jay team will not be
lacking for its own stars, for it is
largely the same group that
finished number 2 in the national
collegiate race last year. Blue Jay
Coach Henry Ciccarone will
change hats for this game,

however, by coaching the Alumni
team. Replacing him as coach of
the varsity team will be

challenge.

rough" and said that there were
almost a few fights. Hopkins

victory.

tri-captains, was injured in the
Villanova game but will be ready
to play this weekend at
Columbia.

Fencing; An Art
and a Sport
ROSALIND RESNICK
Usually reserved for dashing
d'Artagnans and British prep
school graduates, fencing is now
becoming a popular sport for
women, according to freshman
Wendy Galfand. A person who
highly values individuality and
independence, Ms. Galfand says
that fencing disciplines both
body and mind.
Ms. Galfand began to fence at
age 13 when her school's phys.
ed. teacher started a class. In
addition to competing in
interscholastic competitions, Ms.
Galfand has participated in a
national tournament in Michigan
and an international one in Israel.
Before coming to Hopkins, she
worked out at the University of
Pennsylvania with Olympic
competitors. Although the
opportunity to do independent
research was the deciding factor
in her decision to attend
Hopkins, she was also impressed
by the fencing team here.
Unlike tennis, fencing
equalizes the competition
between men and women;

Pi

victory depends on skill, not on
physical strength. Ms. Galfand
says that she fences well against
men, although men are often
quicker and more aggressive.
"Fencing is an art and a
sport," Ms. Galfand says; it
requires skill both to play and to
watch. Fencing necessitates
"point control" to score the five
"touches" needed to win the
match as well as short-term
endurance for thrusting. Ms.
Galfand's exercises include
100-yard sprints and daily
2'4-mile jogs as well as leg work
and arm skills.
Because fencing is a "thinking
sport," Americans do not
support it equally with the
spectator and team sports,
according to Ms. Galfand. In
international competitions,
Americans usually rank lower
than European fencers, who are
quicker, use their entire bodies,
and have better point control and
training.
Although fencing is a major
part • of Ms. Galfand's life, most
of her friends are not fencers.
Her family, she maintains, has
not been alienated by her

The Johns-Hopkins University
varsity lacrosse team will meet
the Hopkins Alumni under the
lights of Homewood Field on
Saturday, October 1, tomorrow,
at 8 P.M. The public is invited to
attend the out-of-season contest
for which there will be no
admission charge.
The Alumni team will feature
many nationally prominent
lacrosse stars, including two
All-Time super-stars, Jack
Thomas and Joe Cowan, each of
whom was considered the best of
his era. Among other
All-Americans to appear for the
Alumni are Stan Fine, presently
Director of the Maryland State
Lottery, and Mt. Washington
midfielder, Stan Kowalchuk.
Also playing will be Mt.
Washington defense star, Dennis
Townsend. who last spring was
selected to play for the USA
World Team.
The star-studded alumni team
includes several former standouts
who are now in the active
coaching ranks. Charlie Coker is
assistant coach at UMBC, Lucky
Mallqnee coaches at Park School,
Jim Moorehead is the coach of
newly powerful Wroxeter, and
Downey Slafkosky is assistant
coach at West Point.
The Blue Jay team will not be
lacking for its own stars, for it is
largely the same group that
finished number 2 in the national
collegiate race last year. Blue Jay
Coach Henry Ciccarone will
change hats for this game,

however, by coaching the Alumni
team. Replacing him as coach of
the varsity team will be

Hopkins' interviews for the Rhodes
Scholarships will be held on
Wednesday, October 12 at 9:30 a.m.
in Homewood House. All students
applying for the Rhodes must submit
a transcript, three letters of
recommendation, a curriculum vitae,
and a statement of purpose to Dean
Suskind's office by October 7. The
Rhodes Scholarship is open to
anysingle U.S. citizen, 18 to 24 years
of age, with a bachelor's degree earned
by October 1978. The Scholarship is
awarded for intellectual ability and
physical vigor and enables the
recipient to study at Oxford for at
least two years.
Applications for the Marshall
Scholarship are available in Dean
Suskind's office in Homewood House.
The Marshall provides opportunity to
study in England for two years, and is
open to any U.S. citizen under
twenty-six years of age with a good
academic background. A clearly
defined program of study is necessary.
The endorsement of the Dean is
required so that a transcript, letters of
recommendation, a curriculum vitae
and the program of study proposal
must be received in the Dean's office
by October 10.

SC to Establish Book Co-o
BY KATHLEEN TROY
The Student Council has
proposed the establishment of a
book co-op on campus which
would offer texts to students at a
lower price than those currently
Offered by the Hopkins Book
Center, the University-based
bookstore. The proposal is not a
new one; the Student Council has
discussed the possibility of setting
Up a co-op for several years. But
if the plan materializes this time,
Hopkins students will be able to
order books at a discount price
starting next semester.
In past years, proposals for the
establishment of a book co-op
have raised questions about the
legality of such a move. The

University has a contract with
Follett's which prohibits the
introduction of a competing
establishment on campus. Dave
Chcsanow, President of the
Student Council, said that the
proposed co-op will not interfere
with the University's contract
because Follett's handles a wide
range of books and supplies that
the co-op will not.
Initially, the co-op will offer
only books for courses that are
being given regularly—either for
the first or second semesters—and
only those books that are
commonly used, required texts.
Books will not be ordered for
courses that are being offered for
the first time or that have a very

limited number of students. In
the beginning, the co-op will try
to benefit the greatest number of
students. Therefore books for
lower-level, and required courses
will probably be the only ones
available. After the co-op nas
established a reliable credit
record with the publisher, books
may be offered for a wider range
of courses.
The co-op would operate out
of the small room across from
the Student Council office on the
second floor of Levering Hall. At
first, students would place orders
for books at the end of the
previous semester, paying cash
when ordering and receiving the

go for the idea of codes 'falling
into disuse.' Laws don't die out,

Mr. Chesanow commented.
According to Mr. Chesanow,
the failure of Dr. Muller to have
the Board ratify the code was
just another step in a long line of
apparent abuses of authority by
the University President.
Dr. Muller gave a differing
explanation for his lack of action
on the code. "The code was
adopted when the position of
Dean of Students was new, so a
fair amount of time and effort
went into making it, and I did
advise the Trustees about it—yet
I quite deliberately did not take
it to the Board for approval so
that it would formally go into
effect. Frankly, we wanted to
gain some experience in such
matters before we locked
ourselves in. By the end of the
year it became apparent that the
kinds of cases that former Dean
of Students Fitzpatrick was
dealing with—and virtually all of
those which Dean Hall has
handled—didn't really lend

themselves to being solved by the
code."
Dean Hall, who succeeded
Dean Fitzpatrick, has said that he
never saw a copy of the code:
"When students came before me
I didn't even mention the code.
It had fallen into disuse. When I
had to make a disciplinary
decision, I simply gave them the
word. Yet I always let the
students know that they had a
right to appeal, The
Administration, though, has
always had the last voice in such
matters."
Presently, the Student
Council's Issues Committee
under Gerry Spada is working on
a new code, and each week
various aspects of it are
discussed. Says Mr. Chesanow,
"We should have it completed by
the end of tile year, hopefully by
the end of the semester. We're
working on it as fast as we can,
bat this time it's going to have to
carry some weight."
Although he has been
operating for four years without
one, Dean Hall is enthusiastic
about the possibilities of a new
code. "Student Council is saying
we should have a part in our own
governance—we are mature
enough to have a part in the
disciplinary process," he
commented. "That's good. It's
part of a very positive Hopkins
tradition of the students taking

responsibility for themselves."
However, President Muller,
who has the last word on the new
code, is not so sure that
unmitigated student and faculty
participation in the disciplinary
process is worthwhile. "The code
was developed retrospectively
when there was some
apprehension on Dean
Fitzpatrick's part that we would
have incidents that might hark
back to the 1960's. We haven't
had incidents like that. In terms
of our experience, I'm not sure
we need a code. That is, we have
in effect operated, for some time
without one. However, that
doesn't mean that I'm opposed
to havipg one and I can foresee
future circumstances where it
would be useful."
Dr. Muller thinks that tile new
code "should be sufficiently
flexible that it could be useful."
Mr. Chesanow agrees in principle.
"The most bidding code will be
the simplest one," he said. "Any
code that is too strict will allow
too mu ,.:h room for
circumvention::
A major aspect of the new
code, according to Mr.
Chesanow, would be a provision
for the formation of a panel
composed of students, faculty,
and administration to dear
special disciplinary cases.
"Perhaps a disciplinary panel
modeled after that of the Ethics

Board is not a bad idea—that
might be the perfect safeguard
against this code falling into
disuse."
Dr. Muller is amenable to the
possibility of a judicial
disciplinary panel, but he would
not want it to override the main
purpose of the Dean of Students'
Office—to handle problems of a
personal nature that involve at
most only three or four students.
"I think what the code has to

preserve is a great deal of
discretion for the Dean of
Students to deal with a case in a
more counseling than judicial
role," he ,commented."Yet if we
had student conduct of a public
and extracurricular nature that
seriously inconvenienced other
students, conduct that would be
susceptible to some sort of
judicial proceeding, then I think
•it would be a good idea to have a
code."

BY BRUCE SMITH
"More Hopkins students
Should apply for post-graduate
scholarships," according to
Student Council President Dave
Chesanow.
Many scholarships are available
for post-graduate studies, yet few
Hopkins students have applied
for them this year. "It's not a
question of capabilities; there are
many Hopkins students who are
Perfectly qualified," said Mr.
Chesanow. "It's bad news that
more students haven't applied.
The personal benefits and
satisfaction of winning such a
scholarship, not to mention the
added prestige that Hopkins
would enjoy, are enormous."
Information and application
materials are available in Dean
Sigmund Suskind's office at
Homewood House.
The Marshall Scholarship
Provides the opportunity to

study in England for two years,
and is open to any U.S. citizen
under 26 years of age with a
good academic background. The
Scholarship is an expression of
British gratitude for the Marshall
Plan. An effort is made to place
the candidate in the British
University of his or her choice.
The endorsement of the Dean is
required so that a transcript,
three letters of recommendation,
a curriculum vitae and the
program of study -proposal must
be received in the Dean's office
by October 10.
Rhodes Scholarships provide
an opportunity to study at
Oxford for two or three years.
The Rhodes, awarded for
intellectual ability and physical
vigor, is open to any singleU.S.
citizen, 18 to 24 years old, with a
bachelor's degree earned by

This drivel is about an American submarine in World War

dusty jokes, and irritating stereotypes. The only
redeeming features of this show are John Astin as the
erudite commander and Leonard Stern, the Executive
Producer, who tries to keep the production values here as
high as in his previous shows, "The Honeymooners" and
"Get Smart."

newspaper, and while the show suffers from the typical
Hollywood journalism cliches, it's fun to watch. MTM
Enterprises, which normally produces comedies, has
turned serious with successful results.

BY SUZANNE SANDERS
From behind and to the right of the stage, trees climb
quickly into tanglewood. To the left, after a bit of fence
and brush, the stream has already attracted waders. Here
we are, out front, covering the slope still damp from last
night's rain. Forming a natural amphitheatre, the sound is
as clear up at the concession stands as it is down close. So
how come it looks like the stage is in a hole?
Workers wearing plastic yellow wrist passes unpack
their gear, explain to each other that a food ticket for 10
cents really means $1, but a quarter is a quarter. Even an
hour before the music, there is a sizeable audience. Many
came in Friday to set up tents or campers, or just to park
the car and start an early party. People carry in whatever
seems appropriate: coolers, a bean-bag chair, nude babies,
lawn chairs, a keg, suntan lotion, joint in one hand and
cigarette in the other. An order has been put in for
sunshine, and looks promising.
The first band, The Chesapeake Bay Retrievers, is
local—from Baltimore, that is. Nearly everyone here is
from the home place. I wonder where all these nice
people are when I'm prowling Greenmount or Charles.
So long as the sun is up, people-watching is foreground,
Officially, I am employed at a concession stand, so I

But the music! It grabs me and suddenly I am dancing.
Stomping or swinging a partner, running in time with the
beat, hopping like a kid on a hot brick. Sweat streams
down from behind my ear, but so long as they play I can
keep jumping! When the song ends, I find I am wrung out.
Looking around, people crumple to the ground. But if I'm
not out of the crowd before the next set, I can't help but
spring alive. Feet moving like fingers on a banjo string.
Connection between audience and musicians is mutually
electric. Dance, pick, scream, saw that fiddle in two!
It's easy to get close to people, not only to dance.
Between the stage and stands there is no light except
cigarette ends and haphazard flashlights. No one will get
insulted at a touch in the dark... faces pulled from shadow

sliver of dew runs down my forehead. The campgrounds
have not been stillAll night. Harmonica player passes in
the dim and first morning birds harmonize. I tell my

Maybe from being in the mist as the sun crawled above,
maybe exhaustion, lends some slowness to tne second
morning. The crowd as a whose is up, dancing, drinking,
charging jeeps and cycles at each other. But I hang at the
edges until afternoon, talking about unseen places or
minding the store. As gn.dually recharging, my sunburned

Someone's cooler makes me a foot taller than those
around me, except when I step down to take out beer. I
tie my shirt up and boogaloo. A roadie wz,ves back when I
wave, Bromberg smiles back when I yell out a request.
(And I know I'm not mistaken, he sang it right to me.)We
scream out the chorus: "You know that same rowdy
crowd that was here last night is back again." After two
encores, I see Bromberg signal to the announcer, no more,
and I wriggle 19.ck out of the crush.
Packing up that evening, I calculate my last seven days
have only included four of sleep. We underhand bread,
cigarettes, hotdogs, everything into the reefertruck.
Impatient, groggy, but still able to tapdance when the
music is right. Turn the customers away. I watch my pack
squashed into the trunk, repeat my address and curl in the
back seat. Can't help but crash...

There are certain
sports at Hopkins that do not
attract great amounts of
attention no matterhow good or
pathetic their season records have
been .. Football is one of those
sports whose record has not been
anywhere near wonderful.
Because of this, 200 fans at the
opening game of the year was all
that turned out. The players,
coaches, and others involved in
the program, though, work as
hard as any other sport. As a
matter of fact, the majority of
the coaches and assistants are
volunteers.
So what do they get for their
effortsi Last year their record
was 3-5-1, 200 fans a game, and
virtually not enough players to
have practices where the coaches
can afford to do any ersatz
hitting. Why do the electrical
engineers and pre-med students
then bother to take the time to
come out for a losing team?
Rick Law, center and
sophomore from Baltimore, is a
superb example of what athletics
at Hopkins are all about. An
environmental engineer major, he
gets none of the breaks that a
football player at University of
Maryland would get. None of the
cars, special tutors, special food,
special dorms, as a matter of fact
the football squad here gets no

special anything. The students
don't even appreciate his
dedication by showing up for the
games.
What Rick does get is a
tremendous sense of a job well
done, camaraderie, and a chance
to get out on that field and
release the tremendous amount
of pressure that the academics
place on aperson at JHU. And he
is good at the center position.
Head coach Denny Cox describes
Law as more than just a super
person. "He's dedicated, loyal
and hardworking, I can't say one
bad thing about him. He does not
rely on pure strength or ability to
get the job done. He leans heavily
on technique. He's the most
consistent offensive linesman for
the past two years."
Student coach Bill McEnroe
only duplicates the coach's high
praise of the team's center.
"Ricky's doing the work in the
trenches. He blocks for the
backs. Most people watch the
ball, and never see the linesman
who tre doing the bulwark. But
they don't want credit. Their
satisfaction comes form within.
When our team scores, within the
team its know who has made the
blocks."
Law himself doesn't want the
credit. "No recognition doesn't
bother me. If I have a good

block, a touchdown block, it's
better than if I was running with
the ball. I work all week for
Saturday. If it was good then I
feel good. If it was a bad game,
then it was all a waste. It ruins
the rest of my weekend. But you
have to put it out of your mind.
But I'll get my credit sooner or
later, the whole team will.
The stereotype that surrounds
football players just doesn't exist
at Hopkins. Jocks aren't
admitted on the basis of their
athletic prowess only. They go
through he regular admissions
process just like the rest of the
students here. Law would never
give up his future in
Environmental engineering to
play at a school like The
University of Maryland with a
superiOr football program, but
terribly inferior academics. "I
wouldn't give up engineering to
play for Maryland. They can't
guarantee the future. 1.m happy
to go to school here. Of course at
Maryland the partying isn't
limited to Saturday like it is here.
Of course at Maryland the
partying isn't limited to Saturday
like it is here. But we only party
here as much as anyone else. I'll
only go to disco night if I have
my work done."
"It's tough coming here as a
freshman and trying to play

football, and study. It's tough
having to do the work without
the athletics, and then add in
three hours a day practicing, plus
the two weeks that come to
school early and live in the dorms
before orientation. Then on top
of everything, the high school
stars that come here expect some
amount of crowds, and then they
get nothing."
The entire football situation at
the Hop then must revolve
,,round something other than the
fans and fringe benefits. The
reward must be personal. Rick
Law is an unsung hero in the
offensive line and an unadmired
football player at Hopkins knows
that only too well." You have to
enjoy it. Some at Hopkins knows
that only too well. "You have to
enjoy it. Some guys are so
emotionally involved after a loss.
You just have to put it out of
your head. No fans affect my
playing only in that I'm not quite
as keyed up as I could be if there
werer a few thousand out there
instead of two hundred.
Physically though it doesn't
affect me that much. I'm ready
emotionally and physically. Of
course it would be an incentive
to play harder if fans were out
there."
BY CHRfISTY JO ANDERSON

BIA
BY JOHN L. BRANDEIS
The Bureau- of Intramural
Athletics (BIA) operating under a
new set of by-laws has opened
the season with flag football.
Participation is high. with six
frats, seven independents, and
nine dorms fielding teams. A
minimum of seven players are
required per team, but generally
there are ten or more eligible
members on each squad. The
frats and independents form one
league with the dorms comprising
another. At the end of October,
the respective league champions
will meet in a final game.
Since this is a contact sport
women are not allowed to play,
but are welcomed in all
non-contact sports. In the past,
co-ed volleyball has been quite
popular,and this year in the
interest of forming a varsity team
there will also be volleyball just
for women.
Other BIA events soon to take
place include the annual Goucher
Gallop, which will he on October
9. It is two and a half miles long,
and if interested contact Steve
Taitz, Box 954. A tennis
tournament in both singles and
doubles competition is currently
scheduled for the same weekend
but may be changed to the
following week. This weekend a
seven mile bike race will occur at
Lake Montebello. It is slated to
I start at 12:30 on Saturday.

Lacrosse
The Johns.Hopkins University
varsity lacrosse team will meet
the Hopkins Alumni under the
lights of Homewood Field on
Saturday, October 1, tomorrow,
at 8 P.M. The public is invited to
attend the out-of-season contest
for which there will be no
admission charge.
The Alumni team will feature
many nationally prominent
lacrosse stars, including two
All-Time super-stars, Jack
Thomas and Joe Cowan, each of
whom was considered the best of
his era. Among other
All-Americans to appear for the
Alumni are Stan Fine, presently
Director of the Maryland State
Lottery, and Mt. Washington
midfielder, Stan Kowalchuk.
Also playing will be Mt.
Washington defense star, Dennis
Townsend, who last spring was
selected to play for the USA
World Team.
The star-studded alumni team
includes several former standouts
who are now in the active
coaching ranks. Charlie Coker is
assistant coach at UMBC, Lucky
Mallonee coaches at Park School,
Jim Moorehead is the coach of
newly powerful Wroxeter, and
Downey Slafkosky is assistant
coach at West Point.
The Blue Jay team will not be
lacking for its own stars, for it is
largely the same group that
finished number 2 in the national
collegiate race last year. Blue Jay
Coach Henry Ciccarone will
change hats for this game,

however, by coaching the Alumni
team. Replacing him as coach of
the varsity team will be
All-American Mike O'Neill.
Two other members of the
Hopkins team that played in the
NCAA finals last year will change
uniforms. Goalie Kevin Mahon

Completing a
successful weekend tournament
here on Saturday, September
24th, the Johns Hopkins Water
Polo team travels this weekend to
New York for another weekend
tournament at Columbia
University, marking the
beginning of their regular season
play.
On Friday, September 23rd
the Blue Jays wiped out Towson
State 27-6. Coach Bob Summers
felt that the Tigers were just
beginning to get into shape and
weren't ready to pose any real
challenge.

Villanova, however, was in
much better shape and gave JHU
a real run for its money.
Sophomore Mark Wolfrom
described the game as "very
rough" and said that there were
almost a few fights. Hopkins
triumphed, nevertheless, 14-12.
Both Coach Summers and his
team felt that it was a good
victory.
The B-team also defeated
Towson State's B-team 16-4. This
coming weekend's tournament
schedules JHU against Syracuse
on September 30th, but since
Syracuse no longer has a water
polo team, Hopkins will probably
receive a forfeit victory. The
15-man travelling team takes on
Lehigh and St. Francis on
Saturday and Washington and
Lee on Sunday.
The tournament at Penn State
will probably be the toughest for
the Blue Jays, mainly because
they will be taking on Slippery
Rock, the No. 1 team last year.
Over the weekend second
string goalie Stever Malloy, a
freshman, suffered a broken hand
and will be out for the season.
Eric Horning, one of the
tri-captains, was injured in the
Villanova game but will be ready
to play this weekend at
Columbia.

Tennis
On Friday, September 30th
the JHU women take a 1-2
record to Lancaster, Pennsylvania
to play Franklin and Marshall
College.

Fencing; An Art
and a Sport
ROSALIND RESNICK
Usually reserved for dashing
d'Artagnans and British prep
school graduates, fencing is now
becoming a popular sport for
women, according to freshman
Wendy Galfand. A person who
highly values individuality and
independence, Ms. Galfand says
that fencing disciplines both
body and mind.
Ms. Galfand began to fence at
age 13 when her school's phys.
ed. teacher started a class. In
addition to competing in
interscholastic competitions, Ms.
Galfand has participated in a
national tournament in Michigan
and an international one in Israel.
Before coming to Hopkins, she
worked out at the University of
Pennsylvania with Olympic
competitors. Although the
opportunity to do independent
research was the deciding factor
in her decision to attend
Hopkins, she was also impressed
by the fencing team here.
Unlike tennis, fencing
equalizes the competition
between men and women;

Pi

victory depends on skill, not on
physical strength. Ms. Galfand
says that she fences well against
men, although men are often
quicker and more aggressive.
"Fencing is an art and a
sport," Ms. Galfand says; it
requires skill both to play and to
watch. Fencing necessitates
"point control" to score the five
"touches" needed to win the
match as well as short-term
endurance for thrusting. Ms.
Galfand's exercises include
100-yard sprints and daily
2'4-mile jogs as well as leg work
and arm skills.
Because fencing is a "thinking
sport," Americans do not
support it equally with the
spectator and team sports,
according to Ms. Galfand. In
international competitions,
Americans usually rank lower
than European fencers, who are
quicker, use their entire bodies,
and have better point control and
training.
Although fencing is a major
part • of Ms. Galfand's life, most
of her friends are not fencers.
Her family, she maintains, has
not been alienated by her

Hopkins' interviews for the Rhodes
Scholarships will be held on
Wednesday, October 12 at 9:30 a.m.
in Homewood House. All students
applying for the Rhodes must submit
a transcript, three letters of
recommendation, a curriculum vitae,
and a statement of purpose to Dean
Suskind's office by October 7. The
Rhodes Scholarship is open to
anysingle U.S. citizen, 18 to 24 years
of age, with a bachelor's degree earned
by October 1978. The Scholarship is
awarded for intellectual ability and
physical vigor and enables the
recipient to study at Oxford for at
least two years.
Applications for the Marshall
Scholarship are available in Dean
Suskind's office in Homewood House.
The Marshall provides opportunity to
study in England for two years, and is
open to any U.S. citizen under
twenty-six years of age with a good
academic background. A clearly
defined program of study is necessary.
The endorsement of the Dean is
required so that a transcript, letters of
recommendation, a curriculum vitae
and the program of study proposal
must be received in the Dean's office
by October 10.

The co-op, though still in the
planning stage, has support from

Dean of Students Jakie Hall is
favorable to the idea of a book
co-op and says that he will
"support it in any way that (he)
can, and will encourage (his) staff
to do the same." Mr. Robert
Duvall, manager of Follett's has
told Dean Hall that he will help
Dave Chesanow with the co-op in
any way that he can. Dean Hall
did point out that there still were
some problems to be solved.
